docs.lead_paragraph: Japanese researchers have found that back-seat riders who are not wearing seat belts pose a deadly threat to those in the front of a car in an accident. The researchers, writing in a recent issue of The Lancet, said 80 percent of the deaths of front-seat riders wearing seat belts might have been avoided in the five years they studied. That amounts to 742 deaths, and it does not include the 1,520 severe injuries that may also have been prevented, they said. In all, the study found, unrestrained passengers in the back increased the risk of death of people in the front almost fivefold.

headline.main: Beltless Human Missile in the Back Seat

docs.abstract: Japanese researchers find that car crash forces back-seat passengers who are not wearing seat belts into back of front seat at immense force, often killing front-seat passengers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Have Americans become a more sensitive lot since Sept. 11, as some predicted would be case? That may be, at least based on what Americans themselves are saying. A survey by psychologists at the University of Michigan has found that people are describing themselves as kinder, more loving and more grateful, according to the university.
docs.abstract: Americans surveyed by psychologists at University of Michigan describe themselves as kinder, more loving and more grateful than they were before Sept 11 terrorist attacks (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The beauty of medicine,'' a medical school adviser once told me, ''is in the gentle surprises.'' A few months ago, I worked the night shift in the emergency room at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.
docs.snippet: ''The beauty of medicine,'' a medical school adviser once told me, ''is in the gentle surprises.''    A few months ago, I worked the night shift in the emergency room at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

docs.lead_paragraph: Painful bladder infections, which send millions of women to doctors each year, can often be treated safely with just a phone call and a prescription. Women treated over the telephone by nurses or doctors who prescribed antibiotics based on the women's symptoms and medical histories are just as likely to recover and be satisfied with their care as women having the usual time-consuming office appointment, a Michigan study has found.

headline.main: Fighting Urinary Tract Infections With a Phone Call

docs.abstract: Study finds that women who are treated for urinary tract infections over telephone by nurses or doctors who prescribe antibiotics based on women's symptoms and medical histories are just as likely to recover and be satisfied with their care as women having usual time-consuming office appointment; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most serious childhood diseases can now be prevented by vaccines, and most bacterial infections can be cured with antibiotics. But one condition now running rampant has no medical preventive or cure. That condition is Type 2 diabetes, and preventing and curing it requires a kind of intervention that only the potential and actual victims can provide: making better food choices, getting more exercise and -- most important of all -- avoiding excess weight or taking it off if it's already there.

headline.main: Diabetes Candidates Can Reduce the Risk

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on alarming rise of Type 2 diabetes in US; says diet and exercise are only means of preventing it in people who are most at risk: those with close blood relatives with diabetes, women who develop gestational diabetes or whose babies weigh more than nine pounds at birth, and people of all ages who are significantly overweight, particularly people who are fat around the middle; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't like snoring? Then, a new study suggests, you may want to look closely at the shape of a potential mate's head. Researchers at the Case Western Reserve University dental school has found that people whose heads are round are more likely to have serious snoring problems than do people with long, thin faces. The report appears in a recent issue of Sleeping and Breathing, a journal published by the Academy of Dental Sleep Medicine.

headline.main: The Shape of Snores to Come?

docs.lead_paragraph: Most of those injured in the World Trade Center attack required only outpatient medical treatment, a new study finds. The finding, reported in The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, a publication of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, gives a fairly detailed look at who was hurt in the attack and the nature of their injuries.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that most of 790 people injured in World Trade Center attack required only outpatient medical treatment; survivors ranged from 1 to 95, with most requiring treatment for lung injuries (387) and eye injuries (204) caused by smoke, dust and the like; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Healthcare Online for Dummies,'' by Howard and Judi Wolinsky, Hungry Minds, $21.99. ''Dr. Ian Smith's Guide to Medical Websites,'' by Dr. Ian K. Smith, Random House, $12.95. As any Web-surfing patient and potential patient knows, the Internet overflows with medical information. Much of it is accurate, clear and reliable, but some is superficial and contradictory and in some cases can be plain wrong.

headline.main: Help in Navigating Health Care Web Sites

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews two books on online Web sites; they are Healthcare Online for Dummies, by Howard and Judi Wolinsky, and Dr Ian Smith's Guide to Medical Websites, by Dr Ian K Smith; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An influential government task force today granted its highest endorsement to the practice of taking aspirin to help people at increased risk of heart attacks. The United States Preventive Services Task Force, an arm of the Department of Health and Human Services, said that for many people, the benefits of regular aspirin use clearly outweighed the risks. The recommendation appears in The Annals of Internal Medicine.

docs.lead_paragraph: People, particularly young children, the elderly and those with weak immune systems, should avoid eating raw sprouts because they may bear salmonella bacteria or other microbes that can cause fatal infections, federal health experts say in a new advisory. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued the advisory last week after investigating an outbreak of a rare form of salmonella last year among more than two dozen people in California, Arizona, Colorado and New Mexico.

headline.main: C.D.C. Issues Warning About Raw Sprouts

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that raw sprouts may carry salmonella bacteria and other microbes that can cause fatal infections, particularly in young children, the elderly and people with weak immune systems; clover, alfalfa and radish sprouts have become popular with health-conscious people because they are high in protein, but they are incubated and grown in moist, humid environment, where they can become contaminated through exposure to feces, untreated water and improperly cleaned harvesting and processing machines (M)
